page.title: 19THE LLINDIR INN, HENLLAN
page.content: Together with the Church and chapel, this picturesque village pub forms a focal point for the local people. It was built as early as 1229 and has thick stone walls and a thatched roof. During the eighteenth century it became a welcome coaching stop on the London to Holyhead route. The inn is reputed to have a ghost which haunts the older parts of the house in the early hours. According to legend,the lady of the inn was murder- ed when her husband returned unexpec- tedly to find her with her lover. The interior of the inn retains its character _ with old beams,wheel-back chairs,copper and brass ware. The Llindir is now the only village hostelry; its companion - the Cross Foxes - closed some years ago.
